pros: Great people try their best to advocate for you and help you move to a more stable position, but they have no power, not really
cons: Constantly Asked to do training at the spot of a moment and figure out excessive amounts of new and varied tech platforms. now Pressured into providing mental health solutions and training for new students in crisis: meanwhile if you’re not on a stable contract…they don’t care if you’re immunocompromised, Simply no opportunity to succeed. Feels set up to fail as a teacher no matter what.

review_title: Student Workers Need to Be Paid More
job_title: Student Graphic Designer in Boone, NC
pros: The position is a great addition to your resume and the design work you do can all go into your portfolio.
cons: The only con is how low the pay is, $8 an hour is impossible to live on without working multiple jobs which is what I am doing. Almost every student worker I've talked to has said they get paid more than me - the dining hall employees, coffee shop baristas, people who work at the library quite literally everyone. Graphic design is a very tedious job and the amount of time that's being put into my work should at least be reflected in the pay. Someone who I previously worked with in our office requested that my pay gets raised to at least $12 and we were denied every single time.

There is an issue of equitability in the pay structure for positions. An Associate Director in one department could have a $7-10,000 difference.

review_title: Overall a great place to work
pros: I have taught in the College of Education and Fine and Applied Arts after receiving an EdD at the university. The full time and part time faculty I studied under and worked beside were vibrant and committed. Two of my sons earned degrees here. One from the Hayes School of Music. The school of music is phenomenal. The school grants 50 incoming low income students first year students a full scholarship. The students I have worked with who received this were highly active in their college. My family has loved living in the beauty of the mountains.
cons: Like many places, it is challenging to live off the adjunct or part time status. The university is swallowing up the mountain town. The university speaks of diversity, and though there is growing cultural diversity, the academic and intellectual diversity feels top heavy.

review_title: It's a great place to visit/vacation ... and a stifling place to live.
job_title: Assistant Professor in Chapel Hill, NC
pros:
Students are engaged.
You'll have an office. Maybe. You will have 7 hours/week of mandatory office hours whether you have an office of your own or not.
cons:
Cost of living.
Salary banding and lack of raises.
Managerial/organizational changes and friction across divisions ensures that turn-over among assistant professors remains high. You will be expected to have an advanced degree in alchemy in order to fund your own projects.
Inter and intra-departmental feuding is part of the culture, along with gossip and various degrees of sabotage as a way of ensuring that junior colleagues on the tenure-track feel the generational, educational, and professional divide between newcomers and lifers.
It's the least diverse institution in the 17-institution UNC system, and the surrounding demographics of the region also reflect this reality.
You will make less and pay more to live there.

pros: Very friendly and supportive administration and colleagues, though I think this would depend on your department. Classes within the School of Music were wonderful to teach because the students are so great. The School of Music in general is a great place to be employed because of the tight-knit nature of the group.
cons: Mostly the students, they can be a handful depending on what course you are teaching. If you ever teach classes for non-majors(regardless of field), be prepared to grow thick skin. They must have put something the water  - entitlement up the wazoo. As an adjunct music faculty member it can be hard to keep a consistent course load, especially if you're new. Unless you have a tenured position-which, let's be honest, are hard to come by these days-the number of classes you teach can fluctuate semester to semester, and therefore your salary does, as well.

review_title: Schaefer Center for the Performing Arts student employee
pros: I got a ton of experience working at a multimillion dollar theatre and working for some of the greatest bands including, Sheryl Crow, David Grisman, Stomp, Little Big Town. We also put on dance shows, jazz performances with special guests in the industry, and film festivals such as Bannf.
cons: Summer work there is very difficult (not really a con personally, but may be for others). The winter ballet is dreadful to work though; 4 year old children weren't the problem, but their mothers got very much in the way.

pros: Great professors and an awesome campus made this university a pleasure to attend. I majored in Anthropology and so most of my experience is relegated to that department, but my minor was in Philosophy and I have nothing but good things to say about them as well.
cons: It's freaking cold in Boone, NC. This is not the place to go if you don't like snow, ice, and weather. The town itself is a nice place and easy to get around, but there is nowhere near enough housing for all the students near campus. Luckily, you will be able to use the free bus system to get to classes from almost anywhere in town.

review_title: If you love mountains and isolation, this is the place
pros: Beautiful campus; sits on top of a mountain; unbelievable summers; real winter (with snow).  Football is the predominant sport and adds lots of excitement to the town.  This is a state university, part of the UNC system, so you get state retirement which is not too bad.
cons: Campus work is predominately made up of locals and relatives.  Some change is in the works but it's nepotism at its best.  Pay can be on the low end.  Opportunities are few.  Housing is expensive and general cost of living is above the norm from my perspective.  Lots of people live "off the mountain" for cheaper housing, greater choices in retail and lower expenses in general.

review_title: Great students to work with but Administration does not value staff
pros:
Students, they are engaged, interested and warm
Beautiful campus
Lots of cultural programs and great exercise facilities
cons:
Staff members are not valued by Administration and therefore many systems and procedures are not well run because Administrators are faculty members who don't have any real world perspective.
Morale is very low and poor managers do not hold people accountable, 
Poor morale is contagious!
Staff pay is a good 25% below that of comparable universities while faculty pay is above, this reflects how staff members are valued and should be a warning.
Patriarchal environment, women beware

review_title: Micromanaged, and too much red tape.  Get with it!
pros: Benefits, some co-workers are great, it's a job and it pays the bills
cons: The procedures for doing some things are absolutely ridiculous.  Still making 3 paper copies of some forms, when the process could easily be stream lined and electronic.  It is 2014, get with it!  To be such a 'sustainable' university, they sure do like their copies, not to mention no electric car charging devices.  The temp hiring process is a nightmare, in which no one really seems to know what they are doing.  I hate being micromanaged, however some supervisors are the opposite. Way too much focus on athletics.  Oh well, it's a job.

review_title: I have been a student employee for food services part time for five years
pros:
-Chances for upward mobility and resume building are available if you are good at your job and try for them
-There are raises every semester
-The company works with your student schedule
-The work is fairly easy and does not interfere much with your school and social life
-You get to work with fun full-time employees and student employees
-Gives you a chance to get to know the business half of the university
-Ample positions to give students an opportunity to work while in school
cons:
-Number of positions for promotion are limited
-Pay raises are small
-Supervisors can be harsh

review_title: Great place to work while going to school
pros: Working as a graduate assistant is a great way to help pay  for graduate school while gaining good experience in a professional work environment. The staff is very considerate in working around your class schedule, yet keep you busy enough to where you are not wasting your time.
cons: It can be hard to get in the hours you need if the department you work with does not have any work for you to do. At times, you have to work with department you are not familiar with in order to get any hours.

job_title: Graduate Teaching Assistant in Boone, NC
pros: Lets you work on campus in the department where you are studying for decent pay. Good practice for speaking in front of groups and learning fundamentals of your chosen field.
cons: Grading can take large amounts of time, especially if you fall behind. 20 hours a week can seem like a large time commitment in a busy semester.

job_title: Research Lab Manager in Boone, NC
pros: Freedom to teach labs your way, even if you do have to follow a book.  Instructors are able to cater the pre-lab lectures how they would like.  Little grading.  Good interactions with students.  Lots of free time for personal research.  Good experience with public speaking.
cons: Some students don't care, especially in gen-ed labs.  Wish there was more flexibility with the labs themselves, some are outdated and could be much more exciting if made current.

job_title: Digital Media Studio Assistant in Boone, NC
pros:
Work around your course schedule
Socials and benefits at the end of semesters
Scholarship opportunities
Work experience and references

Worked for the technology team in the library. Small group of great people who loved helping other people. Training for highly specialized help to other students and faculty and managing of equipment.
cons:
Can be mind-numbingly dull
Repetitive work for minimum wage
You work with mostly other students so they can either be the best thing about it...or the worst

pros: work our own hours at our own pace, Management very felxible in their support for students. As a library page i was able to wear my headphones while I worked.
cons: The pay started at minimum wage and I was told that after a year I would get a raise by a quarter. When the year finally rolled around my boss told me they had gotten rid of the policy and know more raises were being given.

pros:
Flexible hours, excellent support, fun coworkers, and a great experience. I enjoyed my time working in the library. 
Managers were enjoyable to work with. They knew what they wanted done and would explain multiple times if necessary. 
The work itself was simple enough. You are taught how to perform most operations when you are hired. Anything you don't know, you can ask a higher up.
cons:
I don't think there is much opportunity for advancement unless you start working full time. 
As a student I don't know if you would want to worry about that. As a student myself, I was never exposed to advancement opportunities.

review_title: Resident Assistant- Excellent experience, but very draining.
pros:
Leadership experience
Conflict experience
Meet and make new friends
Highest paying student job on campus
cons:
Extremely draining
They recently took away the raise you get from first year to second year as an RA.
Frequently get woken up in the middle of the night

pros: The relationships with other workers is pleasing for the most part. Getting your books for free is a great benefit.
cons: Did not learn any skills for future employment. Management is very unorganized. No one abides by the rules (even the manager has no clue what the rule book states). Awful pay raises (After 3 years I have only had a .25 raise). Everyone has an apathetic attitude.

pros: Great potential in my area. Learning and professional development is always supported. Great office culture and atmosphere.
cons:
Most of the IT seems to have given up. No ambition to take on big projects or really make an impact on student's lives. Most work is done to simply maintain the status quo. The "IT Governance" committees are full of people who have zero technology experience making ill-informed tech decisions, and are so large that they're completely counter productive.

Promotion chances are slim. It takes an act of the Legislature (literally) to get any kind of raise.

review_title: I was a student employee Conservator for the Special Collections Department of the University Library. Very rewarding.
pros: Some of the great reasons to work for the Special Collections Department: freedom to work independently, friendly staff and faculty, sense of purpose and contribution to a lasting legacy, exposure to many different operations, ability to assist supervisors with acquisitions, great advisers.
cons: There were not very many cons to working in the Special Collections department aside from the fact weekly work hours had stringent limits and the ability to garner raises was placed at such a distance many employees would not be able to attain them.

pros: The only show in town in terms of working in Boone, decent pay, positive overall environment. Working there got me through grad school and also helped me save a little extra life money.
cons: Good people to work with, but little communication/interaction with the administration who really control most aspects of the job.A lot of nepotism and cronyism in terms of getting jobs and often promotion involves going through bureaucracy. Pay raises are nearly non-existent for adjunct instructors unless someone higher up really wants you there.

pros: I enjoyed the community and team work atmosphere at Appalachian State University. The encouragement and words of affirmation I received as a part-time employee there really perpetuated my professional career.
cons: I believe Appalachian State University could be a bit more transparent in the way their "CARE team" functions. The training for the Resident Assistant position was phenomenal but the air conditioning was a bit cold.

pros: some of the upsides working at ASU Food services is that they allows for a flexible schedule, short hours,it  has friendly coworkers and allows career development opportunities.
cons: Some of the downsides working at ASU Food Services are that they are somewhat unorganized and it can be hard to get questions answered when you need them.

pros:
I have worked at ASU for almost six years.  The first three as an instructor and then in a tenure track.  The campus is beautiful.  The employees are usually very friendly and care about the students and the University.  The salary is better than most of the private colleges but not as good as the other UNC sister Universities.  
The Chancellor cares about the University's image, the staff and the faculty.  She has been thrown under the bus for some tough decisions she has had to make but is trying to improve the University.  She has had to put pressure on faculty who have been there a number of years and really not done very much to move the University along.  Most people do not know what she has actually done to assist the staff, faculty and students.  It is true the Deans have all left, but more than a couple of them needed to move on, so growth could happen.  Many of the faculty said negative things about Dr. Peacock and he was the best Chancellor I ever worked with and for, so take that into consideration.
Diversity has improved since the new Chancellor has been in place.
I will give you an example about management and you can take it for what it is worth: I have had four chairs in my department since I began working at ASU.  None could take the Dean for more than a couple of years.
cons:
Some department heads are discriminatory and use bullying tactics to get what they want.  I think with new Deans in position, this will hopefully be eliminated.  We will soon see.
It is true, there is no - to little release time for research endeavors and again this has to be approved by department heads and they use favoritism to provide for those they like.  

Yes, there are still some issues in upper management, but the Chancellor is working on those areas.

pros: Making connections with other students you might normally not run into on-campus. Student run, and fellow employees are usually team players. Friendships develop outside of work in this family oriented environment.
cons: Some events keep you until after 1am, and that can be tough when you have classes that same morning. At times, highly inebriated patrons may try you patience.

review_title: University Tutorial Services is an Excellent Place to Work
job_title: Tutoring Lab Manager in Boone, NC
pros: The full-time staff at UTS is very friendly and supportive. My training was done by the Director of UTS, Jessica Lorello, and by the Support Services Director Wes Waugh. They both made me feel very comfortable approaching them with questions and held regular meetings with all part-time staff to address issues and update us on any changes that had been made to the tutoring lab protocol. The work environment was likewise very calm, friendly, and enjoyable.
cons: I have nothing negative to report about University Tutorial Services or its staff.

pros: It's a great place to work because as a student, I can choose the hours, as long as they are available.  The full-time staff is very helpful, friendly, and great people to talk with.  I developed wonderful working relationships with those around me.
cons: Some managers didn't put in as much work as others- they stood around and talked with employees.  The raise for each semester is nice, but I would like to offered more with the amount of effort I put in to being a trusted worker.

review_title: ASU is one of the only places to work in Boone. Any job is better than no job.
job_title: Nightstar-Night Resident Assistant in Boone, NC
pros: Steady hours and decent pay. Get a small raise every semester and get recognized for a job well done. As long as you show up you wont lose your job.
cons: There is absolutely no room for advancement, and manager of housing and residence life doesn't really care about her employees.

review_title: Good experience until I was about to graduate
pros: The job is easy money. Most of the time you are just sitting around and watching participants or counting how many people are using the gym.
cons: The sitting around and watching people can be really boring. The permanent staff is really good at micromanaging and constantly looking over your shoulder.

pros: Appalachian State provides a great opportunity for students to gain a valuable education. The faculty and staff are knowledgeable and willing to help students with whatever needs they may have.
cons: Appalachian State is located in the mountains and therefore is rural in relation to major cities. Charlotte is the closest city at 90 miles distance.

review_title: Employment here had the potential to be great, but the school ultimately failed by hiring and promoting poor performers.
pros: Chance to work with a few great people. Chance to contribute to the success of the educational system. Chance to be in a prime location for outdoor activities.
cons: Unending bureaucracy. Toxic organizational culture in places. Too few excellent employees. Too much focus on athletics; often to the detriment of other critical university initiatives.

review_title: Good for flexible hours; not for everyone
pros: They work with your schedule and you only have 2 or 3 mandatory events a year. You can also learn some new skills while there and if you work there long enough, you can get set hours. Can keep you active.
cons: The boss can be overly harsh, and hours can run long depending on the event. Though, after a couple weeks, you can usually tell what will and what won't. Can be tiring

pros: Had a great chance to get an inside look of the administrative side of App. Both of my advisors were very helpful and never hesitated to help me work through the steps of anything I had a problem with. I worked at my own pace and never had an issue meeting deadlines. Definitely a great experience!
cons: Majority of the hours spent was doing website update and administrative work...in other words, lots of paper work.

job_title: Director of Student Development in Boone, NC
pros: The students are great and almost make it worth living with poor management and very low pay.
cons: The pay is horrifically low and poor management makes this even more difficult to take.  It's the Appalachian way!

pros:
They understood that I was a student, and allowed me to work very flexible hours. 
They provided fair compensation for the work I did.
My department was a small team of mostly student employees, and it was a very friendly atmosphere.
cons:
There is very little upward mobility, but that's to be expected for student employment opportunities.
The technology I worked with was a bit old and well used.

pros: I only worked at Appalachian as a graduate assistant, but it was a well-paying job for the area. I never had an issue getting my paycheck. Obviously as a student your supervisor will depend on many factors, but I had only positive experiences at App as a student employee.
cons: You have to purchase your own parking pass, which is expensive, but parking in Boone is very limited, so this is understandable.

review_title: Good university, good students, administration is changing hands but morale has been low
pros: Supportive department environment for academic freedom; resources for facilities and teaching supplies not bad; good faculty and students
cons: Provost needs to go (but appears to be on her way out); salaries are terribly compressed

review_title: Electronic Student Services Undergrad Web Dev - V good Experience
job_title: Student Web Developer in Boone, NC
pros:
- Great experience
- Nice people to work with
- Yearly trips to an open source tech conference in Raleigh - all paid
- Entirely flexible hours
cons:
- Can only work 20 hours, even during the summers
- Raises are hard to come by or are unfair in comparison to other coworkers

pros:
Boone is beautiful in the summer if you're willing to put up with winter.
State benefits are great.
cons:
There is no pet policy for live-in staff.
Accountability is hard to find when colleagues do not do their work.
Mental health issues are draining with little to no life balance - see con #1.
Colleagues at other UNC schools are compensated better (7-10k more) and have pet policies in place.

pros: Great school and great people. Good work experience. Various opportunities available. Caring towards students.  Love the seasonal changes in Boone.
cons: I cannot think of any, I really enjoyed working there and was a student at the time. Snow of course can be crazy at times, but it is beautiful.

pros: It's a great place to work as a student. They work with your school schedule and make sure that you are working one something that you will like.
cons: Sometimes it can be difficult to get all of the paperwork handled in an efficient manner for pay, but overall the place has people working that love what they do.

pros: I loved my job and wish I could go back. It was perfect setting, and everyone was always extremely nice and cooperative.
cons: It was only open from 8-4 and having classes sometimes made it difficult to get good hours.  If you showed up and did your job though, he was really fair about giving you all you needed.

pros: I love working at App because my co-workers genuinely care about my well-being. I also get great experience working at a university, which is what I want to do when I graduate. They have extremely flexible schedules for student workers, which I love.
cons: Obviously, once I graduate I won't be able to work here.

job_title: Graduate Teaching Assistant in Boone, NC
pros: Compensation roughly matches tuition after 1 year of experience.
cons: You're still on the hook for living expenses, full time assistance-ship doesn't cover it. They try to find you an assistance-ship, but if there isn't one available they don't make any guarantees about  assistance.

pros: Great real-world development experience provided in team environments, useful resources abound
cons: Some uses of antiquated technologies, not necessarily relevant languages used - some projects are in poor shape when inherited, multi-year projects not advised due to poor codebase and lack of structure

job_title: Office of Admissions Student Caller in Boone, NC
pros: Positive atmosphere, great management, great opportunities to gain experience especially in customer service, relaxed atmosphere.
cons: Occasionally could be repetitive, although management does a good job integrating new tasks to break to monotony.

pros: Great experience working for Appalachian State's graduate program; being a TA, GA, or RA are all great options, and for a grad student, the pay is reasonable
cons: It can be a bit difficult juggling school and home work with being a graduate assistant, but it's still a great deal, regardless

pros:
Flexible work hours
fun staff
management is nice
cons:
lack of marketing
abundance of meetings, a few too many

review_title: awesome place and students, poor leadership and low intellectual ambition
pros:
awesome place
wonderful students
some wonderful colleagues and staff
cons:
low intellectual curiosity
very, very, parochial
too little diversity
no interest in research
little transparent procedures, especially when it comes to spending
too many searches ending up hiring the local candidate

pros: Staff members care about the professional development of the graduate students to ensure they are gaining the proper skills transferable to their future path.
cons: Graduate Assistant packages aren't as good as certain peer institutions.

pros: friendly staff, enjoyable working environment, engaged with the campus, nice location in the mountains, typical benefits for a staff position
cons: strict working regulations, low budget departments, stupid hierarchy within departments, salaries on the low end, tough winters and seldom cancellations

pros: App has the right people in charge, and is aggressively evolving into a nationally-prominent masters-comprehensive
cons: Ongoing diversity issues -- change must happen faster. Difficulty retaining faculty of color needs greater institutional focus.

review_title: You’re pretty much disposable. The company does not care about you..
pros: The cheap meal plan and gym access
cons: They put all over the place. Once you get comfortable in an area you get moved again. They do not care about what you wan. They are controled by money and politics.

review_title: Great and fun place to work at
job_title: Graduate Research/Teaching Assistant in Boone, NC
pros: Always received pay on time, answered any concerns I had about the job, and loved working with the students.
cons: Challenging to deal with some of the rules by the University on disciplinary action for students

pros: Appalachian really supports it's students, and is a great place to work. A lot of the people employed are students.
cons: I don't believe that there are any downsides to working on campus. It's convenient and the pay isn't bad.

review_title: Student worker's perspective in tech support
job_title: Computer Support Technician in Boone, NC
pros:
Flexibility with scheduling around classes
Friendly and helpful supervisors
Training provided and continued as needed to expand responsibilities
cons:
Often clients are difficult to work with
Parking is impossible
Limited to 20 hours a week

pros: Appalachian State University is located in Boone, NC. You can't ask for a more beautiful location to live or work in.
cons: The pay is beyond minimal. They do not pay a living wage for GTAs and GRAs.

pros: I was a student working part time. I love Appalachian, it's a great place to work and a great place to go to school.
cons: Worked there for 3 years and never got a raise.

pros: Great faculty supervisor, reasonable expectations, fantastic pay
cons: Lack of communication, sometimes assumes too much responsibility

job_title: Student Resident Assistant in Boone, NC
pros: very organized, lots of resources, caring bosses, on campus, close
cons: large university setting, demanding hours, can't leave job when you live where you work, still have to pay for housing, challenging co-workers

review_title: I loved my graduate experience at ASU!
pros: I loved my graduate experience at ASU!
cons: Must have good time management to be in graduate school and have a graduate assistantship.

pros: Access to campus gym, parking, and other things for a small small fee.
cons: Taken advantage of, no room for promotion, favorites are obvious.

pros: Loved the people I worked with, could be fun at times, could get into shows you didn't work for free
cons: not very flexible, late work hours, dealing with rowdy students, high turnover

job_title: Graduate Research Assistant in Boone, NC
pros: Flexible schedule, good pay, nice staff!
cons: Sometimes disorganized administration, lack of information about certain forms and paperwork!

review_title: Great school full of wonderful people!
pros: Everyone is kind and willing to help you. People care if you are being mentored and want you to succeed.
cons: I can't think of any.

job_title: Information Systems Analyst in Boone, NC
pros: Appalachian State Univ is a great diverse location to work and live.
cons: Cold windy winters other than that a perfect place to live and work

pros: Flexible hours, they work with your class schedule
cons: Low pay, you can work enough to make decent money but it takes a lot of your time

job_title: Graduate Research Assistant in Boone, NC
pros:
Exposure to how professors run their classes.
Flexible hours that fit your class schedule.
cons: At times there is a large amount of work that could interfere with course work.

job_title: Child Development Center Aid in Boone, NC
pros: flexibility as a student worker, direct deposit, ease of obtaining tax forms, closed on holidays and for inclement weather.
cons: I really can't think of any :)

job_title: Graduate Research Assistant in Boone, NC
pros: laid back, helpful faculty that makes time for students
cons: lack of diversity, equipment is not new nor state of the art

pros:
Every  employee is excited to promote the University. 
Beautiful campus, very updated office space.
cons: Poor communication skills and understanding from the Chancellor.

pros: Compassionate community, beautiful outdoor recreation, wonderful neighbors, safe town, great weather.
cons: The only con is if you don’t like small towns, it’s a small town.

pros: Beautiful City, Great students
cons: Atmosphere changing as it grows.  Not a family feeling anymore, Cost of living is very high

pros: The staff cares about all there students and staff and the hours are flexible beyond compare!
cons: Minimum wage but its made up with hours and flexibility

pros: flexible schedule, understanding upper management, awesome environment
cons: not a lot of disciplinary action, sometimes professional lines are blurred and that makes working difficult

pros: Flexible hours, satisfaction, choice of what you tutor
cons: Tutoring is hard for normal kids to get...service is focused on special needs and athletes.

review_title: Excellent GA opportunities in Biology department
pros: provided with excellent training and support, TA assignments provide valuable experience
cons: no guarantee of summer assistantship after first year

pros:
Great hours however you dont get to choose
Great Pay
Wonderful People
cons: working as a GA and getting your masters is a lot of work

review_title: Management is great but depends on your RD
pros: In general helpful and supportive to staff

job_title: Graduate Research Assistant in Boone, NC
pros: Fantastic Experience, Excellent Guidance, Top-Notch Staff
cons: It's Research, so if you don't like it, you won't like this

pros: you can add it to your resume
cons: doesn't pay a lot and you can't get many hours if you are a student employee.

pros: Flexible work hours, Great Coworkers, Mostly Stress Free.

pros: Flexible hours and exceptional co-workers who are wonderful to work with.
